name: Business Architecture
description: Business capabilities, processes, and organizational structures

capabilities.name: Customer Management
capabilities.definition: Capability to acquire, retain, and manage customer relationships throughout their lifecycle, ensuring optimal customer experience and business value creation.
capabilities.description: Customer Management encompasses all processes, technologies, and strategies used to interact with customers across all touchpoints. This capability enables organizations to understand customer needs, deliver personalized experiences, and build long-term relationships that drive business growth.

maturityLevels.description: CRM system in place, some automation

capabilities.name: Financial Management
capabilities.definition: Capability to manage financial planning, budgeting, and reporting across the organization
capabilities.description: Financial Management encompasses the processes, tools, and strategies used to plan, manage, and report on an organization's financial resources. This capability ensures financial transparency, regulatory compliance, and supports strategic decision-making through accurate financial insights.

capabilities.name: Supply Chain Management
capabilities.definition: End-to-end management of goods and services from suppliers to customers

capabilities.name: Human Resources
capabilities.definition: Management of workforce planning, talent acquisition, and employee development

capabilities.name: Risk Management
capabilities.definition: Identification, assessment, and mitigation of business risks

capabilities.name: Product Development
capabilities.definition: Innovation and development of new products and services

name: Application Architecture
description: Software applications and their interactions within the enterprise

capabilities.name: Enterprise Resource Planning
capabilities.definition: Integrated software platform managing core business processes
capabilities.description: Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) provides a unified suite of applications that streamline and automate critical business processes such as finance, procurement, supply chain, and human resources. ERP enables consistent data sharing, process efficiency, and real-time insights across the enterprise.

maturityLevels.description: Basic ERP in place for core functions

capabilities.name: Customer Relationship Management
capabilities.definition: Technology for managing customer interactions and relationships

capabilities.name: Business Intelligence
capabilities.definition: Analytics and reporting capabilities for data-driven decision making
capabilities.description: Business Intelligence (BI) enables organizations to transform raw data into actionable insights through reporting, dashboards, and interactive analytics. BI helps stakeholders monitor performance, identify trends, and make informed strategic decisions.

capabilities.name: Collaboration Tools
capabilities.definition: Platforms enabling team communication and collaboration
capabilities.description: Collaboration Tools facilitate effective communication, information sharing, and teamwork within and across organizations. These tools enhance productivity, especially in distributed or hybrid work environments.

capabilities.name: Content Management
capabilities.definition: Systems for creating, managing, and publishing digital content
capabilities.description: Content Management enables organizations to efficiently create, organize, store, and distribute digital content across channels. It ensures content consistency, brand integrity, and supports marketing and operational needs.

capabilities.name: Integration Platform
capabilities.definition: Middleware connecting disparate systems and applications
capabilities.description: An Integration Platform enables seamless data and process flow between different applications, systems, and services. It reduces complexity, improves agility, and supports both real-time and batch integrations across the enterprise.

name: Data Architecture
description: Data assets, storage, and management across the organization

capabilities.name: Data Warehousing
capabilities.definition: Centralized repository for storing and analyzing large volumes of data

capabilities.name: Master Data Management
capabilities.definition: Unified, consistent view of critical business data across systems

capabilities.name: Data Lake
capabilities.definition: Storage repository for raw data in native format until needed

capabilities.name: Real-time Analytics
capabilities.definition: Processing and analyzing data as it arrives for immediate insights

capabilities.name: Data Governance
capabilities.definition: Framework for managing data availability, usability, and security

capabilities.name: Backup & Recovery
capabilities.definition: Protection and restoration of critical business data

name: Infrastructure Architecture
description: Physical and virtual infrastructure supporting business operations

capabilities.name: Cloud Computing
capabilities.definition: On-demand delivery of computing services over the internet

capabilities.name: Virtualization
capabilities.definition: Creation of virtual versions of computing resources

capabilities.name: Network Infrastructure
capabilities.definition: Hardware and software resources enabling network connectivity

capabilities.name: Storage Systems
capabilities.definition: Hardware and software for storing and managing data

capabilities.name: Monitoring & Management
capabilities.definition: Tools and processes for monitoring infrastructure health

capabilities.name: Disaster Recovery
capabilities.definition: Strategies and tools for recovering from infrastructure failures

capabilities.name: Infrastructure as Code
capabilities.definition: Provisioning and managing infrastructure using machine-readable configuration files
capabilities.description: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) enables automated, repeatable, and scalable provisioning of infrastructure resources. By treating infrastructure definitions as code, organizations can apply software engineering practices such as version control, testing, and continuous delivery to infrastructure.
examples: Terraform scripts to provision cloud resources

capabilities.name: Container Orchestration
capabilities.definition: Automated management of containerized workloads and services
capabilities.description: Container orchestration simplifies the deployment, scaling, and operation of application containers. It automates key tasks such as service discovery, scheduling, scaling, and self-healing of containers across clusters.

capabilities.name: Service Mesh
capabilities.definition: Dedicated infrastructure layer for managing service-to-service communication
capabilities.description: A service mesh provides observability, traffic management, and security for microservices communication without changing application code. It supports consistent policies across distributed systems.
benefits: Decoupling of networking logic from code

capabilities.name: API Gateway
capabilities.definition: Centralized entry point for managing and routing API requests
capabilities.description: API Gateways act as the front door for applications and services, handling tasks such as request routing, authentication, throttling, and logging. They simplify client interactions with backend services.
examples: Apigee as an enterprise API proxy
benefits: Rate limiting and protection from abuse

capabilities.name: Observability
capabilities.definition: Ability to understand system behavior through logs, metrics, and traces
capabilities.description: Observability enables teams to diagnose issues, optimize performance, and understand system behavior in real time. It integrates logging, monitoring, and distributed tracing to provide a complete picture of system health and user experience.

capabilities.name: Secrets Management
capabilities.definition: Secure storage and access control for sensitive credentials and secrets
capabilities.description: Secrets management ensures that credentials, tokens, keys, and other sensitive configuration data are handled securely across environments. It provides access control, auditing, and integration with deployment workflows.
examples: AWS Secrets Manager for storing API keys

capabilities.name: CI/CD Pipeline
capabilities.definition: Automated build, test, and deployment of application changes
capabilities.description: CI/CD pipelines streamline the software delivery process by automating code integration, testing, and deployment. They enable faster feedback cycles, reduce human error, and support DevOps practices.

capabilities.name: Edge Infrastructure
capabilities.definition: Compute, storage, and network resources located closer to the end user
capabilities.description: Edge infrastructure supports low-latency, high-performance workloads by deploying infrastructure components geographically close to users or devices. Itâ€™s essential for use cases like IoT, AR/VR, and real-time analytics.
examples: CDN edge servers for content delivery

name: Security Architecture
description: Security controls, policies, and technologies protecting the enterprise

capabilities.name: Identity & Access Management
capabilities.definition: Framework for managing digital identities and access permissions

capabilities.name: Endpoint Protection
capabilities.definition: Security solutions protecting end-user devices and endpoints

capabilities.name: Network Security
capabilities.definition: Technologies protecting network infrastructure from threats

capabilities.name: Security Monitoring
capabilities.definition: Continuous monitoring and analysis of security events

capabilities.name: Data Protection
capabilities.definition: Technologies and processes protecting sensitive data

capabilities.name: Vulnerability Management
capabilities.definition: Process of identifying and remediating security vulnerabilities
